A star whose life ended in a cataclysmic explosion has been recorded by the recently installed National Astronomical Observatory in Gozo.  The star lies in the so-called Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) which lies around 21 million light years away.  â€œThis means that the event actually happened 21 million years ago, the light of the explosion having travelled across the universe since that time until it finally reached us,â€ said Prof. Joseph Caruana, from the University of Maltaâ€™s Department of Physics and Institute of Space Sciences and Astronomy.  The event in question is known as a Type II supernova. This occurs when a massive star â€“ several times more massive than our sun â€“ is unable to sustain nuclear fusion any further, thus undergoing a rapid collapse that ends with a catastrophic explosion.  The supernova, dubbed SN 2023ixf, was reported on the 19 May by Koichi Itagaki. A notification system for astronomers around the world allows them to follow up with further observations.  â€œYesterday, some amongst the amateur astronomy community in Malta â€“ the Astronomical Society of Malta â€“ were already discussing this object with us,â€ said Caruana, who recorded the image throughout the night of Saturday 20 and Sunday 21 May, remarking that it was quite exciting to witness such an event just a few days after the observatory in Gozo had started operating.  â€œWhen you look at the image, the supernova looks just like a tiny dot amongst many others. But that tiny dot represents an extremely violent event whose light has travelled an immense distance. It really gives you pause.â€  Astronomers around the world â€“ both professional and amateur â€“ will be turning their telescopes to this object over the coming days. Observations of such events often involve collaboration between professional and amateur astronomers.

The Caloocan City Police Station (CCPS) reported that a man fired a handgun and lobbed a grenade in front of the office of the Northern Police District- Drug Enforcement Unit (NPD-DEU) in Barangay 14, Caloocan City on Saturday, May 20.  Gen. Ponce Rogelio PeÃ±ones, Northern Police District (NPD) director, said they have already identified the suspect.  According to the police report, the man immediately fled towards Pampano Street after firing his handgun and throwing a hand grenade that exploded in front of the office near the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group (CIDG) office at around 1:45 a.m.  The CCPS Explosive Ordinance Division (EOD) recovered three fired cartridges, a slug, and metallic fragment from the exploded MK-2 hand grenade.  CCPS Chief Col. Ruben Lacuesta said the explosion damaged the front stairs of the police station.  He said that they also found bullet holes in the officeâ€™s main door and on the surface of the car parked in front of the office.  Authorities have withheld the identity of the suspect who is now the subject of a manhunt launched by the CCPS.  Investigators are eyeing retaliation against the police anti-illegal drugs campaign as one of the possible motives behind the attack.  No one was reported injured in the incident.

BENTON â€” For the first time since 2019, residents, vendors and visitors flocked to the Benton Alewife Festival on Saturday to celebrate the native fishâ€™s resurgence in recent years.  The festival began in 2012, but was canceled for a few years due to the coronavirus pandemic. It celebrates the annual alewife migration, when the fish travel upstream for about a month in the spring to reach lakes and ponds to spawn.  â€œWeâ€™re hoping to continue bringing a greater awareness to the importance of the alewives and the Sebasticook River, and also to come together as a community,â€ said organizer Amy Gagnon earlier this week.  Festivalgoers congregated Saturday at the Benton Riverside Park by the town hall to browse stalls offering food, canned goods, wood carving demonstrations and information on local wildlife including alewives. People could then migrate down a walking path from the park to the Benton Falls Dam for a tour of the fish lift at the dam. Live music from bluegrass band The Oystermen provided the dayâ€™s soundtrack.  At Benton Falls, tens of people at a time lined the dam, leaning over the railings to catch a glimpse of the millions of fish passing over using a fish elevator.  Itâ€™s a recent marvel: for decades, alewivesâ€™ migration up the Sebasticook River was blocked. In 2008, the fish population at Benton Falls was estimated at just 400,000.  Advertisement  But the removal of the Edwards Dam on the Kennebec River in Augusta and the Fort Halifax Dam in Winslow, along with other restoration efforts, now allow the fish to travel up again. In 2022, there were an estimated 2.7 million fish counted at Benton Falls Dam, according to the Maine Department of Marine Resources.  Festivalgoers were eager to celebrate that fact on Saturday for the first time in years.  â€œItâ€™s good to have these kinds of community events opening up again,â€ said Benton-based forest ranger Timothy Kjellman. Kjellman was on hand to represent the Maine Forest Service and teach local kids about fire safety and wildfire prevention.  A couple vendors had made an annual appearance at the festival before it was suspended, including wood carving instructor Steven Valleau, an artist-in-residence at the Wendell Gilley Museum in Southwest Harbor.  â€œI feel like now Iâ€™m back here, COVID is officially over,â€ Valleau joked. â€œItâ€™s awesome.â€  Also returning with a stall were representatives from the Sebasticook River Land Trust, on hand to explain to people headed down to the falls the importance of alewives to the area, and raise awareness about ongoing conservation efforts across the watershed.  Advertisement  Doug Wescott, a land trust board member, said that alewives are hugely important to the regionâ€™s watershed.  â€œThereâ€™s a big issue in a lot of lakes in Maine with phosphorus,â€ Wescott said.  Phosphorus is an essential nutrient for plant life but when there is too much of it in water it can speed up something called eutrophication, which causes a dense growth of algae and depletes oxygen levels.  Alewives, Wescott said, eat the algae produced by excess nutrients in the lake like phosphorus, effectively cleaning up the lake and mitigating the potential for an algal bloom.  The removal of the dams was a godsend to the Sebasticook River watershed, Wescott said. â€œThey were interfering with natural processes â€¦ I donâ€™t think anyone knew at the time how many alewives would come here.â€  Since then, the Sebasticook has become one of the biggest alewife runs on the East Coast. Wescott said that the 5-mile section of the Sebasticook River in Benton and Winslow has become the area with the largest concentration of bald eagles on the East Coast.  â€œAnd itâ€™s all because of the alewives,â€ he said. SAN DIEGO (AP) â€” Rafael Devers homered twice and drove in four runs to help the Boston Red Sox beat San Diego 6-1 Friday night to hand the staggering Padres their 10th loss in 12 games.  Devers and his friend and former teammate, Padres shortstop Xander Bogaerts, took the lineup cards out for the pregame exchange and hugged. Devers then circled the bases in front of Bogaerts in consecutive innings in his 14th career multi-homer game.  Devers hit a solo shot to right so hard leading off the second that he stumbled back a few steps before starting his trot. He hit a three-run homer nearly to the base of the batter's eye in straightaway center field with no outs in the five-run third for a 6-0 lead. He has 13 homers this season.  Both came off lefty Blake Snell (1-6), who allowed six runs and five hits in four innings.  Before the game, Bogaerts said he hoped Devers didn't hit any homers because â€œhe's a dangerous guy. He's truly one of a kind."  Devers proved his friend right.  â€œVery happy today that I was able to hit two runs but you have to keep doing adjustments every day,â€ Devers said through a translator.  â€œHe put two great swings,â€ manager Alex Cora said. â€œAround him, everybody put up good at-bats. That was impressive, the third inning. We were grinding at-bats, fouling off pitches, staying on pitches, taking our walks. It was a fun inning.â€  Rob Refsnyder hit a two-run, bases-loaded double ahead of Devers' three-run shot to help the Red Sox to their third straight win.  Other than Fernando Tatis Jr.'s leadoff homer in the third off James Paxton (1-0), the Padres' offensive struggles continued on a day when slugger Manny Machado went on the 10-day injured list with a hairline fracture in his left hand. The Padres were booed at game's end, just as they were Wednesday after a loss to Kansas City. They fell to five games under .500 and are 8 1/2 games behind the NL West-leading Los Angeles Dodgers and just one game ahead of the last-place Colorado Rockies.  The Padres managed just Tatis' homer, his sixth, and four singles in six innings off Paxton, who was making only his second start of 2023. He made his Red Sox debut a week earlier, his first big league appearance since April 6, 2021, with Seattle. He missed most of the 2020-22 seasons due to injuries and had Tommy John surgery on April 12, 2021.  â€œIt feels great, just really to contribute to the team and be here pitching again,â€ said Paxton, who earned his first victory since Aug. 15, 2020, against Boston while he was with the New York Yankees.  Paxton said Devers is "awesome. His swing is amazing. So good on offense and he does a great job at third base, too. Just an all-around fantastic player, fun to watch.â€  Josh Winckowski pitched the final three innings for his second save.  Bogaerts, who left the Red Sox as a free agent and signed a $280 million, 11-year contract in December, was robbed of a single by diving right fielder Alex Verdugo to end the fifth.  EXPLOSION IN SINGLE-A CLUBHOUSE  Two contract workers were burned in a natural gas explosion in the home clubhouse of the Lake Elsinore Storm, the Padres' Class-A affiliate, leading to Friday's game being postponed. The two workers were taken to a hospital. The Padres said no players were involved.  DEVERS AND BOGEY  Devers and Bogaerts went out to eat Thursday, an off day for both teams. â€œYou know what's crazy is, I forgot my wallet at home. I'm not even kidding," Bogaerts said. He thought he left it at the ballpark but didn't find it there, and started to get nervous. â€œI said, 'Man, you've got to pick this up. I don't even have a dollar.'" Bogaerts said he found his wallet at home, in his backpack, where he put it during the bus ride home from Dodger Stadium last Sunday. â€I haven't told him that piece yet but I told him right away that he's got to pay,â€ Bogaerts said.  TRAINER'S ROOM  Red Sox: 1B Justin Turner, who was aboard for Devers' three-run shot, left the game with left knee soreness.  Padres: Machado's was hurt when he was hit by a pitch Monday night. His IL stint is retroactive to Tuesday. Manager Bob Melvin said thereâ€™s a possibility Machado can return when the Padres play at the New York Yankees next weekend.  UP NEXT  Saturday night's game will feature a marquee matchup between Red Sox LHP Chris Sale (3-2, 5.40 ERA) and Padres RHP Joe Musgrove (1-1, 6.63).

GRAND ISLAND, Neb. (KSNB) - When it comes to bombs and explosives we often think of police department bomb squad, but firefighters have some knowledge on that too.  During the 86th annual Nebraska State Fire School, they learned about explosives in one of the featured classes.  Nebraska State Patrol educated firefighters about different elements that compose an explosive device. They even were treated to seeing a few explosions to understand the power packed in each kind of explosive.  â€œMany people donâ€™t think about that,â€™ said Jimmy Lawson, Class Coordinator at Nebraska State Fire School. â€œThat this is going to be a situation involving some type of explosive but they need at least the basic training. Enough to understand the dangers, safety precautions, and certainly enough to protect themselves before they go rushing in and getting hurt themselves.â€  For some firefighters, it was about just knowing the resources exist.  â€œWell I think that we learned that we have, that Nebraska has available resources for us as firefighters and the general public and that it happens more than you think and that itâ€™s all about safety; so we learned a lot today,â€ said Kalah Bergmann, firefighter at Gretna Fire Department.  Fellow Gretna firefighter, Sarah Graselwicz said she learned how to recognize explosives and will be able to used that each time she responses to a call.  Copyright 2023 KSNB. All rights reserved.

HELENSâ€™ ERUPTION: SURVIVORS RECOUNT THE â€˜DARKER THAN MIDNIGHTâ€™ FURY IN 1980  Mexico is no stranger to volcanic activity due to its location along the Pacific Ring of Fire.  The country is home to dozens of volcanic mountains, with several that are considered to be active.

At a vicious PGA Championship, the only joy is misery  Share on Facebook  Share on Twitter  Share by Email  Rory McIlroy survived through a brutal Saturday at the PGA. He's one of the few. Getty Images  ROCHESTER, N.Y. â€” As he stood over the chip on the 17th hole that could well sink his PGA Championship, Rory McIlroy looked, well, miserable.  His face wore a pained expression. His hands fidgeted in small, sudden movements. He talked with his caddie and longtime friend, Harry Diamond, in frustrated quips. He walked in staccato strides to the green and back, searching for some clue on how to execute.  He stepped up to the ball. He paused. He stepped away. He stepped up again. He committed.  And then â€¦ an explosion of sound â€” not the literal kind â€” erupting from the 15th green just a 5-iron away.  Rory stepped off his ball again. He turned back to Harry exasperated. If looks could kill, McIlroyâ€™s might well have had the strength of a cruise missile.  But looks canâ€™t kill, and so Rory had no choice but to play his short-sided wedge shot off a tight, greenside lie and up toward the flagstick â€¦ for par. For the moment, the cruise missile sounded better.  His ball scared the hole for just a second, electing instead to settle neatly just a short putt away. McIlroy would have to take bogey, his fourth and final of the day at Oak Hill. As he walked away from the flagstick he looked up at the sky. For the moment, his tournament had been saved.  McIlroy is a demonstrative golfer, but his experience on Saturday afternoon at the PGA Championship was not an unusual one. Misery was the only path to contention on Saturday at Oak Hill, which has proven as proper and demanding a major championship test as we have seen in professional golf in some time.  Misery in the rain. Misery in the mud. Misery off the tee. Misery around the green. It was everywhere.  The only people who managed were those with the mental makeup to endure such disenchantment for the better part of five hours. It should come as no surprise that also amounts to a whoâ€™s who of major championship stalwarts. On Saturday night, the first seven names on the leaderboard feature the last names Koepka (six under), Hovland (five under), Conners (five under), DeChambeau (three under), Rose (two under), Scheffler (two under) and McIlroy (one under).  â€œI think this tournament and especially in these conditions and on this golf course, the non-physical parts of the game I think are way more important this week than the physical parts of the game,â€ McIlroy said after it was over Saturday, his body language still recovering from the beating. â€œI think Iâ€™ve done those well, and thatâ€™s the reason that Iâ€™m in a decent position.â€  The eighth name of the leaderboard, however, is not a major championship regular â€” nor a professional golf regular. He is PGA teaching professional Michael Block, who may be about the last person anyone expected to see six strokes off Koepkaâ€™s six-under lead come Sunday morning. Block was the cause of the eruption of noise on the 15th green behind McIlroy, his birdie on the hole igniting the upstate New York faithful.  Whatâ€™s Blockâ€™s secret? Well, he may be the only PGA professional in the field silly enough to think he belongs there. And, as it turns out, he just might.  â€œNo. I mean, if anything, I love Rosey, but I can compete against these guys,â€ he said Saturday. â€œI can compete against them. I can hang. I can post a three or four under tomorrow, especially if I get the fairways rolling again.â€  Block might not have a Tour proâ€™s driving distance or putting ability, but he has a major championâ€™s delusion. That, it turns out, was an absolutely essential piece of the puzzle in an inch of rain Saturday at Oak Hill, when no reasonable person would have believed earnestly that it was an enjoyable experience.  â€œI doubt if anybody on this entire property loves golf as much as I love golf. Period,â€ he said. â€œ[One day] Iâ€™ll look back at this week and Iâ€™ll say, â€˜Iâ€™m glad you enjoyed it. Iâ€™m glad you enjoyed the moment.'â€  Koepka, your 54-hole leader, certainly enjoyed the misery. A month after a decidedly uncharacteristic Sunday fade at the Masters, he stalked around Rochester like a hungry lion. On a day when only nine golfers shot rounds under par, Koepka shot 66, posting the round of the day by two strokes and placing himself a stroke clear of the field heading into Sunday.  â€œLearning what I learned at Augusta kind of helped today. To just never think the way I thought going into the final round. I wonâ€™t do it again the rest of my career,â€ Koepka said, although he chose not to elaborate on exactly what that thinking was. â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean that you canâ€™t go play bad â€” you can play good, youâ€™ll play bad â€” but Iâ€™ll never have that mindset.â€  Koepka entered Saturday with a sideshow within reason: his first major pairing with Bryson DeChambeau since the start of an acrimonious feud at this very tournament two years ago. But if there was a circus on Saturday, Koepka didnâ€™t notice.  â€œIâ€™ll be honest with you, I donâ€™t pay too much attention to who Iâ€™m playing with,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t talk a lot. Iâ€™m more focused on what Iâ€™ve got to do. Especially today with the rain, trying to stay dry, there are other things to have to worry about.â€  As we turn to Sunday, itâ€™s unlikely the agony will stop. The weather will improve for the final round, but the challenge will not. Who knew the road to glory was paved with broken souls?  Evidently, McIlroy, who shared an all-too-familiar grimace when asked if he thought he could find a final-round 65.  â€œI hope so,â€ he said, pausing briefly. â€œI need to keep hope.â€  On Sunday, the PGA Championship will crown a winner. But right now there are no winners.  Only survivors.

Itâ€™s hard to fathom the size of the universe. But two Stony Brook University professors are part of a project designed to do just that â€” an effort scientists say is making advances.  Researchers in the NASA-backed project last week published an article in the journal Science detailing their work, which was done largely with the Hubble Space Telescope.  Simon Birrer, an assistant professor in Stony Brookâ€™s Department of Physics and Astronomy, called the study â€œa milestoneâ€ and cutting-edge in trying to determine the size of the universe.  The team consists of about 30 scientists from around the globe, with the majority in the United States. They include the lead author, Patrick Kelly from the University of Minnesota.  WHAT TO KNOW Two Stony Brook University professors are among the scientists participating in a NASA-backed project trying to determine the size of the universe.  are among the scientists participating in a NASA-backed project trying to determine the size of the universe. The researchers focused on a particular supernova â€” or a star that suddenly dissolved through an explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously.  on a particular supernova â€” or a star that suddenly dissolved through an explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously. By comparing where the supernova first appeared to where it appeared a year later, the scientists got an idea of how far away the supernova is â€” and by extension how large the universe might be.  Their focus was on a supernova â€” or a star that suddenly dissolved through a catastrophic explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously. This one was, as Birrer put it in a bit of Star Wars lexicon, spotted in 2014 â€œin a galaxy far, far away.â€  Sign up for the Suffolk news this week newsletter The biggest news, politics and crime stories in Suffolk County, in your inbox every Friday at noon. By clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.  Researchers saw the supernova, called Refsdal, through NASAâ€™s Hubble Space Telescope.  The scientists predicted where they would see yet another image of the very same light flare of the supernova exploding in 2015, which would give them an idea of how far away the supernova is â€” and by extension how large the universe might be.  They were correct. The supernova Refsdal explosion was indeed visible again that year at the location they expected, Birrer said.  It wasnâ€™t easy to find the supernovae, yet alone one that appears multiple times at different locations, due to a phenomenon called gravitational lensing, he said. Plus, supernova explosions are relatively rare â€” perhaps one every 40 years in a galaxy.  â€œThe measurement of the expansion rate of the universe is a roller coaster,â€ Birrer said. But this project was an important advancement.  â€œThe prediction and subsequent observation of the fifth image of Supernova Refsdal was a great success,â€ said Anja von der Linden, an associate professor in Stony Brookâ€™s Department of Physics and Astronomy who also took part in the study.  Von der Linden was part of the team that originally discovered Supernova Refsdal and prepared the follow-up Hubble observations.  Birrer was focused on the analysis of the measurement study, including the examination of the images of the supernova captured by the Hubble.  Soon, the researchers will be adding to their work a next-generation telescope in Chile, South America, called the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, which is especially geared to spot supernovas over a large area of the sky. Using it, they hope to locate about 50 supernovae a year.  Birrer said they got â€œextremely luckyâ€ in spotting supernova Refsdal with the Hubble telescope because it has a far smaller field of view and the timing had to be just right. The addition of the telescope in Chile should allow scientists to find supernovas at a rate 100 times faster, he said.  Sherry Suyu, an associate professor at the Technical Institute in Munich, Germany, who was not involved in the study, said spotting supernovas the way the researchers did has â€œbeen very rare until now,â€ but with the addition of the telescope in Chile they â€œare expected to have hundreds of such events. We are entering an exciting era with lensed supernovae!â€  Wendy Freedman, a professor in the University of Chicagoâ€™s Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, who also was not involved in the study called its findings â€œan interesting and important contribution toâ€ figuring out the size and history of the universe, though some issues remain to be resolved before scientists can get a final, more accurate figure.  Grasping the size of the universe is a somewhat mind-boggling exercise. The solar system with the eight planets including Earth that are revolving around the Sun is part of one galaxy â€” the Milky Way. And the Milky Way Galaxy has some 100 billion stars â€” the Sun is just one of them, Birrer said.  In the universe, there are tens of billions of galaxies, all with about as many stars as the Milky Way Galaxy, he said.  â€œItâ€™s hard to grasp the dimension, even after studying the universe for more than a decade myself,â€ Birrer said, adding, â€œI guess we have to accept that we are just little fish in a big ocean.â€  He added that it has been hard for humans to learn much about the universe, because it is so massive and inaccessible to travel to.  What scientists have learned mostly â€œcomes from just staring at it and see what the universe reveals to us,â€ he said. â€œOur detective work is probably very similar to that of archaeologists. Astrophysicists are able to collect tiny fragments of the past and have to reconstruct a rich and dynamic history of the universe that still holds back many mysteries."  As recently as 500 years ago, scientists and everyone else still believed the Earth was the center of the universe and our solar system, with the other planets and Sun revolving around it. It wasnâ€™t until Nicolaus Copernicusâ€™s studies in the 1500s that we understood the Earth and other planets revolve around the Sun.  Scientists estimate the age of the universe at between 12.6 billion and 13.6 billion years. The new research project should also help calculate the number more precisely, Birrer said.

ST. LOUIS â€“ Itâ€™s graduation weekend for thousands of students in the St. Louis area. St. Louis University alumni John Oâ€™Leary didnâ€™t graduate at the top of his class back in 1999, but he does have a harrowing and inspiring story he shared with new SLU graduates.  Back in 1987, Oâ€™Leary watched a group of older children in his neighborhood playing with fire and gasoline. He was in a horrific accident and given a 1% chance of survival.  â€œI assumed, if they can do it, so can I,â€ said Oâ€™Leary. â€œWith my parents gone, I walked into the garage, bent over a can of gasoline, and poured a little bit of fluid on top. [A] huge explosion, [I] find myself engulfed. [I] spent five and a half months in burn center, burned 100 percent of my body, lost my fingers.â€  Oâ€™Leary attributes his professional success to his time at SLU, and he left the Class of 2023 feeling moved and empowered.  â€œWhat a phenomenal commencement address,â€ Rodney Mosquito said. â€œItâ€™s an honor to be in the presence of someone who has overcome so many challenges. It just reminds me that I can do anything if I put my mind to it.â€  SLU graduate Chloe Kepros added, â€œItâ€™s awesome to hear from someone whoâ€™s also a fellow SLU student and who has been through things and come out the other side and is able to show, you know, where their life is now.â€  But Oâ€™Leary stays humble.  â€œI was not an elite student and would not have been voted most likely to succeed,â€ he said.  Close Thanks for signing up! Watch for us in your inbox.  And he didnâ€™t always feel comfortable sharing what happened to him.  â€œI was invited by a Girl Scout to speak at her school,â€ he said. â€œAnd I made the mistake of saying yes. So that first event led to another, and another, and another.â€  Now heâ€™s spoken 2,600 times in front of millions of people.  â€œNot out of arrogance or ego, but to serve the one in front of us,â€ he explained.  He is grateful for his parentsâ€™ unconditional love. In 2004, they wrote a book called â€œOverwhelming Odds.â€ Now, Oâ€™Leary has written two books himself.  â€œI have a book called â€˜On Fire,â€™ [and] another book is called â€˜In Awe,â€™â€ he said. â€œTheyâ€™re both bestsellers. Just recently there are individuals in Hollywood who realized, man, we want this story to go far beyond St. Louis and far beyond books or speaking.â€  As the Class of 2023 navigates the ups and downs of their own life stories, Oâ€™Leary wants them to remember this: â€œWhether theyâ€™re in the front row or the last row, their life matters.â€  St. Louis University also recognized Oâ€™Leary as an honorary degree recipient on Saturday. Around 3,000 students are graduating from SLU this month.

For a long time, parishes relied on word of mouth to attract new people to join them in celebrating the Mass and the sacraments, either through a personal invitation from a parishioner or the pastor himself. Bulletins, pulpit announcements, and emails were the go-to communication tools for leaders to keep parishioners informed. Seeing the cultural and religious shifts happening around him and the explosion of new forms of technology, St. John Paul II met with the Pontifical Council for Social Communications in 2002. Before imparting his Apostolic Blessing on the people and work of the council, he shared his concerns and challenged his brother bishops and sisters in Christ to take advantage of new opportunities:  â€œThe Gospel lives always in conversation with culture, for the Eternal Word never ceases to be present to the Church and to humanity. If the Church holds back from culture, the Gospel itself falls silent. Therefore, we must be fearless in crossing the cultural threshold of the communications and information revolution now taking placeâ€¦  â€œTherefore, dear Brothers and Sisters, I urge you, in all your planning, to make room for Christ. In the print media, in radio and television, in the world of cinema and the Internet, seek to open doors to him who so mercifully is the door of salvation for us. â€œFast Xâ€ is now out in cinemas everywhere and with it has come plenty of chatter regarding the filmâ€™s numerous cameos, the cliffhanger ending previously teased by its stars, and the various turns the story takes.  MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD FOR â€œFAST Xâ€  The filmâ€™s director Louis Leterrier has spoken with several outlets about some of the creative choices made in regard to the film. First up, he chatted with EW about John Cenaâ€™s character Jakob and his death.  In the filmâ€™s final action set piece, Jakob is transporting Domâ€™s son Brian (Leo Abelo Perry) to safety when Dante (Jason Momoa) kidnaps him. Dom pursues him, but Jakob realizes he must protect Dom and the kid â€“ sacrificing himself to kill Danteâ€™s men in a massive explosion.  The move marks the end of Cenaâ€™s involvement in the franchise following his introduction as the villain in â€œF9â€. Letterier says the death was an idea he came up with early on after meeting Cena â€“ and the news upset the actor a bit:  â€œIâ€™m like, â€˜That man can be a badass but cannot be a bad guy. Thereâ€™s no mean bone in his body. I said to John, â€˜You will have to sacrifice yourself, to give the ultimate gift to your brother to save his son,â€™ and it upset him. I pitched him between two takes as Iâ€™m over there resetting the camera. I pitched him this thing and then he loved it. And that literally changed his performance because he understood where he was going. â€˜Iâ€™m going to give so much love so then the sacrifice really hurts.â€™ And it really does hurt.â€  Of course, does anyone really die in this franchise? The series is famous for resurrecting multiple seemingly dead characters, and does so again here with at least one of the cameos being Gal Gadot returnning as Gisele â€“ last seen fallout out a plane in â€œFast 6â€. The reveal has raised the obvious question as to whether Han (Sung Kang) knew Gisele was alive the whole time.  Gadot confirmed her return a few hours ago on Instagram, posting photos and saying: â€œMissed my Fast family! Iâ€™m overwhelmed with excitement. To my fans, your continuous love and support fuels this journey. Hereâ€™s to honoring the legacy, the fans and the Fast Family that weâ€™ve built together!â€  Meanwhile, the film ends on a cliffhanger with a plane explosion seemingly taking out at least four regulars (albeit behind a hill) whilst Dante prepares to blow a dam that could seemingly kill Dom and his son.  â€œFast X Part 2,â€ whether it be the second half of this story of the middle part of a trilogy, is slated to debut in 2025.

Before the match against Muchova, Camila made her fans dream with two great victories. Now, Karolina will face the Spanish beauty Paula Badosa in the next match.  Camila also revealed her dream: "I love playing in Rome: it's a beautiful city and I'd like to live there one day. I took a ride on a scooter, even if it's a bit dangerous, through the centre, between the monuments and it was wonderful.  And then I like people, you can talk to everyone, and it's all very simple. Former KGB and security boss Nikolai Patrushev told of a 'radioactive cloud' drifting across Europe after Russian strikes hit a uranium supply - the claim has since been debunked as propaganda  Apocalyptic claims from one of Putin's closest henchmen of a radioactive cloud heading across Europe have been ridiculed by experts.  The doomsday prediction was made by Nikolai Patrushev, who has alleged the deadly cloud was wafting west from Ukraine after Russian troops hit an arms depot containing depleted uranium ammunition supplied by the UK government.  Ex-KGB Patrushev is secretary of Russia's security council and reportedly one of warlord Putin's closest security aides and maintained flames erupted high into the sky in a fiery mushroom cloud after the hit.  But after declaring Poland had already seen soaring levels of radiation following the strike, Patrushev was quickly shut down by experts who described the claims as propaganda.  â€œTheir destruction caused a radioactive cloud now moving towards Western Europe,â€ Patrushev's statement said.  â€œAnd Poland has already recorded an increase in radiation.â€  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  The former FSB chief and war hawk also claimed at a meeting in Syktyvkar: â€œFurthermore, the US is developing and already using chemical and biological weapons, including in Ukraine.  â€œSo thatâ€™s what American aid and democracy is all about.â€  Russian state TV which prominently broadcast Patrushevâ€™s claim said he was referring to a strike on a facility in Khmelnytskyi.  â€œA column of smoke from the explosion rose several hundred metres and a prolonged detonation followed,â€ stated Channel One.  â€œThen there was a rise in radioactivity in the area.â€  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  But experts from Khmelnytskyi National University had â€œdebunked Russian fakes about an increase in radiation levels in the city following the attack by Russian forces on the night of 13 May,â€ reported Ukrinform.  â€œPreviously, Russian propaganda began spreading information on social media and news channels about an increased radiation background in Khmelnytskyi, allegedly caused by an explosion damaging either low-enriched uranium shells or components of a bomb sent to Ukraine.â€  A statement from the university said: â€œThere is no reason to be concerned.â€  In Lublin, Poland the Maria Curie-SkÅ‚odowska University said a supposed rise in radioactivity in the country - as highlighted by Patrushev - was a natural phenomenon linked to rainfall.  A spike in bismuth was caused by precipitation.  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  Independent Russian journalist Ilya Shepelin said: â€œAt its peak, on Monday, it wasâ€¦.five million times lower than a life-threatening dose.â€  Patrushevâ€™s radioactive cloud threat late on Friday was mocked by the Procurator Telegram channel which ridiculed the septuagenarian as a candidate for â€œa medal in the field of nuclear physicsâ€.  â€œPerhaps Patrushev forgot to put his glasses on, and did not see that the uranium was depleted, and therefore there was no way a radioactive cloud could come out of it,â€ it stated.  â€œIn a word, the Europeans will not even notice this nightmarish threat, just like the infamous freezing [from halted gas supplies] in winter.â€  Similarly, Patrushev provided no evidence for the constantly repeated Russian claim that the US is developing and deploying chemical and biological weapons in Ukraine.  Image: Getty Images) Getty Images)  In March, Russia accused Britain of triggering â€œgenocideâ€ by supplying Ukraine with depleted uranium tank shells.  Putin said he â€œwill have to respond properly since the collective West will be using weapons with a nuclear componentâ€.  Britain accused the Russians of â€œdeliberately trying to disinformâ€ over a â€œstandard component and has nothing to do with nuclear weapons or capabilitiesâ€.  But Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova hit back declaring: â€œThe use of ammunition with depleted uranium is a manifestation of genocide of the population against which it is used and the people who use them.â€  They would cause radioactive damage to â€œeveryoneâ€ living in the place where the depleted uranium tank shells are released.  â€œThey receive it, and itâ€™s not a one-time problemâ€¦they will live with this forever.â€  This was a â€œscientifically proven factâ€ based on their use in former Yugoslavia, she alleged.

If you were to make a wild stab at which books were the most popular, what would you choose? Your personal favourites â€” say, mysteries, or big sagas, blockbuster reads from writers such as John Irving or Stephen King?  The book industry is having a fine romance: with books about love.  Romance for a new generation  One of the authors who has helped cement the place of romance in the popular imagination â€” or at least on the bestsellers lists â€” is Colleen Hoover. Her â€œIt Ends With Usâ€ was the No. 1 bestselling book in Canada in 2022. According to BookNet Canada, Hooverâ€™s books alone drove a 55-per-cent increase in the romance category when compared with 2021, with five of her titles topping the list.  The same trend was seen in the United States. Publishers Weekly reported that â€œunit sales of fiction titles rose 8.5 per cent over 2021, led by a 52.4-per-cent increase in sales of romance books.â€ And those sales were driven in large part by, you guessed it, Colleen Hoover.  â€œThe list of bestselling romance titles in 2022 is â€¦ led by Colleen Hoover, whose â€˜It Starts With Usâ€™ and â€˜It Ends With Usâ€™ topped the romance charts. Those two books, along with a handful of other Hoover titles, resulted in a banner year for Simon & Schuster â€¦â€  Hoover is published in Canada by Simon & Schuster, which noted in an email to the Star that the author has sold more than 24 million copies of her English-language books â€œin all formatsâ€ across the world. It has seen its sales of romance books â€œskyrocketâ€ as a result.  Much of this traffic is driven by younger readers. According to BookNet Canada, the hashtag #RomanceRecs has more than 390 million views on TikTok, â€œan undeniable source of influence on book-reading behaviour.â€ Itâ€™s an observation that Simon & Schuster echoes.  â€œAn increasing number of younger, and often more diverse readers have discovered and embraced this genre, much of it fuelled by BookTok,â€ the publisher said in a statement. â€œWhere sales have traditionally been driven by retailer merchandising and press coverage, a lot of the original buzz for these books was driven by enthusiastic BookTok readers.â€  The Harlequin effect  There used to be a saying: that 4.1 Harlequin romances sold around the world every second. That particular publisher was, at one time, the first name that sprang to mind when the words â€œbooksâ€ and â€œromanceâ€ were mentioned.  And itâ€™s still going strong. Dianne Moggy, vice-president of editorial for the Harlequin Brand Group, which includes 11 category lines, noted that they publish more than 800 romance titles a year. And theyâ€™re not all those paperbacks we remember from our parentsâ€™ bookcases or grocery store shelves: roughly 40 per cent of their books sell digitally.  The genreâ€™s popularity has driven a deep change in the content of books and an increased focus on giving readers what they want.  â€œWeâ€™ve really been trying to increase the representation across every series we publish,â€ Moggy said. â€œSo weâ€™re trying to ensure that our readers are actually seeing themselves reflected in the books â€¦ whether itâ€™s race and ethnicity or body image or neurodiversity.â€  Those concerns have translated into sales in the Canadian market. BookNet Canada recorded that sales in romance featuring LGBTQ characters increased by 10,406 per cent between 2017 and 2022, with sales from 2020 to â€™21 increasing 301 per cent, and from â€™21 to â€™22 by 136 per cent. Fiction romance in the workplace rose by 1,793 per cent during that five-year period, and for African American and Black categories by 1,733 per cent.  The desire for more representative romance is an aspect of the genre that attracts Muslim writer Uzma Jalaluddin, whose latest, â€œMuch Ado About Nada,â€ comes out in June.  â€œIâ€™m attracted to the subversive aspects of romance, the ways that romance writers (like myself) use the tropes and expectations of this genre to explore other issues, such as identity, immigration or prejudice,â€ she said. And so she writes love stories set in immigrant neighbourhoods with South Asian, Muslim characters.  â€œWhen I wrote â€˜Much Ado About Nadaâ€™ I set it in a massive Muslim conference in Toronto,â€ said Jalaluddin. â€œAs much as my book is a swoony second-chance romance, itâ€™s also about Muslims having fun and inviting the reader into their space.  â€œAfter all, love is love no matter who you are, how you dress or what you believe. Also, no one else was writing them. (Iâ€™m glad thatâ€™s changing now.)â€  Stomping on the tropes and using them in new ways  HarperCollins, whose parent company News Corp. bought Harlequin from the Toronto Starâ€™s parent company, Torstar Corp., for $455 million in 2014, is like many publishers, increasing the number of trade paperback or hardcover romances it offers.  â€œI think the definition of romance has spilled into a number of different areas,â€ said Margaret Oâ€™Neill Marbury, a VP at HarperCollins, responsible for trade titles at the company that owns Harlequin.  Popular American writer Curtis Sittenfeld, who publishes with Random House, has recently waded into the genre with her latest novel, â€œRomantic Comedy.â€  It sets up an interesting dynamic, showing at first the typical dorky, not-so-good-looking guy with the gorgeous model. Then she flips that trope on its head by having the dorky, not-so-gorgeous writer develop a crush on a famous pop star who used to date models.  The book becomes an examination of gender relations and the rituals of romance, yes, but it also does something traditional romances do: has an emotional arc, strong characters you can relate to, some drama that keeps them apart and, well, a happy ending.  â€œI thought that it would be fun. That was my main motivation. I started it in the summer of 2021,â€ said Sittenfeld in an interview. â€œSo it was the pandemic, I guess it was about 15 months or 16 months in, and it felt like a pretty dark time, I think, globally and personally. I definitely wrote â€˜Romantic Comedyâ€™ for escapist pleasure for myself. And then I hoped, eventually, for readers.â€  â€œSome people will say that romance is just ChickLit reinvented,â€ said Canadian author Chantel Guertin, whose latest book is â€œTwo for the Road.â€  She argued that romance now is not â€œa 20-something girl whoâ€™s bumbling through life trying to find a guy. Now the heroines are so strong and they are self-assured, and very successful and have great careers. That romance element is part of it, but as a person they have got it figured out.â€  And, while in the more traditional romance, the happy ending is a must, commercial or trade fiction stories donâ€™t always have to have one, Marbury said, â€œbut they do have to be hopeful,â€ and there still has to be a strong relationship or pull between the characters. Think of writers such as Nicholas Sparks, Emily Giffin and Jojo Moyes.  The â€œhappily ever afterâ€ is the point  But the happy ending has a big role to play, and a lot of readers and writers like it that way.  Romance book sales grew throughout the pandemic, a time of uncertainty, as Guertin pointed out. â€œWe often felt as if we had no control of our situations and we certainly didnâ€™t know what things were going to look like in the next few months.  â€œOnce you know the book is going to end happily, you remove that layer of unsettling and uncertainty, and then you actually enjoy the ride of the journey of the story, which actually is often very complex,â€ Guertin said. â€œAnd you can really delve into the characters and their stories because youâ€™re not concerned about how itâ€™s going to end.â€  And you can escape from the reality of the everyday.  Jalaluddin, too, is a believer in the happily-ever-after ending. â€œPartly this is because Iâ€™m a hopeless romantic, wrapped in the outer trappings of a cynic,â€ she said.  â€œBut mostly itâ€™s because Iâ€™m attracted to optimistic stories that demonstrate the good in humanity; and romance novels, with their focus on love, relationships, problem-solving, a dash of adventure or intrigue, are at their heart heaped with optimism. It is baked into the very DNA of the genre, because no matter what else happens there will be a happy ending for all. Who can resist that?â€  Certainly not the readers buying those millions of romance books being sold every year and those who, during the pandemic, turned to the genre for an emotional and psychological lift.  Can artificial intelligence write us a love story?  As romance continues to modernize its approach, it seems as if it might be particularly vulnerable to being written, perhaps unknowingly to readers, by artificial intelligence, including ChatGPT and others. With its fairly predictable structure, it would seem a particularly promising genre for AI to target.  â€œWeâ€™re not looking to AI to generate content at all,â€ said Moggy. â€œBut itâ€™s a big concern in terms of the number of submissions we get and how do we police that?â€  She noted that they received a submission earlier in the week we spoke and werenâ€™t sure whether it was AI-generated or not. â€œBut it certainly is very similar to another book we have published.â€  While AI might be helpful in terms of writing marketing copy based on metadata, for example, when it comes to the creative process and content, â€œthatâ€™s where I get very nervous about things,â€ said Marbury.  Itâ€™s romance, after all. And doesnâ€™t it all come down to love? Can an algorithm capture emotion? Itâ€™s a question weâ€™ve been asking since Hal in â€œ2001: A Space Odyssey.â€  â€œI think youâ€™ve hit the real point here,â€ said Moggy. â€œCan it bring the emotion, which is what the reader connects to â€¦ if that emotion is missed, then I think youâ€™d miss what the romance reader is looking for.â€  Hopefully, for the industry â€” and writers and readers â€” this will result in a happy ending. And just like that, Kamron Beavers is an Ole Miss Rebel. The four-star defensive lineman out of Bay Springs, Miss., committed to the Rebels on Sunday evening.  "I wanna thank my family and friends and Bay Springs Bulldogs for making me who I am today, and thanks to Ole Miss for giving me a chance to succeed in life not just football," Beavers said on Twitter.  The 6-3, 260-pound Beavers is rated as the nation's No. 17 defensive lineman and the No. 4 prospect in the state of Mississippi's 2024 class by the industry-generated 247Sports Composite index. He is rated as the nation's No. 18 defensive lineman and the No. 4 player in the Magnolia State by 247Sports.  Beavers delivered the news to Ole Miss defensive coordinator Pete Golding and defensive line coach Randall Joyner.  "Ole Miss was surprised," Beavers told Inside the Rebels. "I kept telling them that I was going to commit during the season, but I committed today, so they were surprised."  Beavers chose Ole Miss over offers from Alabama, Auburn, LSU, Mississippi State, South Carolina, Texas A&M, Texas, Texas Tech, Louisville, Miami and Colorado. Beavers said his decision boiled down to a top three of Ole Miss, Alabama and Mississippi State.  Beavers plans to visit and camp with the Rebels next month.  "Yes sir. It's in June that I think I will be up there," he said.  "They really could put me anywhere in my opinion. They're trying to get me situated to a 4-I alignment," said Beavers.  Beavers has lost down from a high of 305 pounds to a slim and meaner 260, he says.  "I've been trying to get faster. It's been working," he laughed.

Idukki: Four persons were arrested for illegal possession of explosive substances and unauthorized quarry operation under the guise of readying a plot for building purposes at Purapuzha near Thodupuzha on Saturday.The arrested have been identified as Jomon John of Palathinadiyil House, Kummachira; Thottathil Basil Joy of Kanjikuzhi, Chemala Saji Stephen of Moonilavu and Thaiparambil Shibu of Manakkad. As many as 40 gelatin sticks, 36 detonators, a sparking machine, an earthmover, and other equipment used for blasting were also seized by a police team led by Thodupuzha DSP Madhu Babu.Using a house construction permit issued in the name of Pennamma John, 67, of Palathinadiyil House, her son Jomon John, 46, and the quarry operators started blasting in the area and transported several loads of rocks. The DSP said that there was no sanction to transport the rock and no nod was given to use explosives. . TNN

Thank you for supporting our journalism. This article is available exclusively for our subscribers, who help fund our work at The Baltimore Sun.  The Baltimore City Fire Department responded to a chemical leak at a W.R. Grace and Company facility in Hawkins Point shortly after 6:30 a.m. Friday.  â€œUnits have mitigated the incident without any known injuries. The leaking vessel has been removed from the scene,â€ fire department spokesperson Michael Winn said.  Advertisement  The incident occurred at 5500 Chemical Road, Winn said.  In an email, Maryland Department of the Environment spokesperson Jay Apperson said a vacuum truck leaked 50-75 gallons of nitric acid, adding â€œthere is no off-site impact.â€  Advertisement  â€œThe truck was inside a temporary secondary containment structure that had been set up as a precaution before the release. The leaking gasket was secured and the truck was relocated to the facilityâ€™s on-site wastewater treatment plant for the remaining material in the truck to be neutralized and treated. Soda ash was applied to the spilled acid in the containment area to neutralize that material,â€ Apperson said.  â€œThe facility or a contractor is responsible for cleaning up the spill,â€ Apperson emailed.  W.R. Grace and Company, a chemical company based in Columbia, said Friday afternoon there was no harm done.  â€œThere has been no harm to our employees, contractors, the surrounding community or the environment. We are taking all proper measures to investigate its cause,â€ W.R. Grace spokesperson Tracy Pogue said in an email.  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, nitric acid is a colorless liquid used to manufacture fertilizers and dyes, among other purposes. Exposure to the acid can cause discomfort, such as skin or eye irritation, or more serious health problems like lung inflammation and bronchitis.  City Councilwoman Phylicia Porter said her office scrambled Friday morning to communicate information to constituents about the latest potential environmental disaster in the area.  â€œThis particular community has existed with these types of environmental harms for generations, I am doing everything possible within my officeâ€™s capacity to defend and advocate for them, but the environmental injustice and racism that is happening is totally disheartening,â€ Porter said. â€œThere is no reasonable follow up. Weâ€™re trying to change that.â€  Advertisement  In December 2021, an explosion at coal plant operated by railway company CSX in Curtis Bay created an enormous shockwave across the city but did not injure any workers. A year later the Maryland Department of the Environment settled with CSX for a $15,000 penalty and $100,000 to a local nonprofit â€” the South Baltimore Community Land Trust â€” for an environmental project. Curtis Bay residents are currently suing CSX over health concerns related to coal dust.  In March 2022, a fire at Petroleum Management Inc. in Curtis Bay killed a 52-year-old employee. Friday afternoon, residents called on Governor Wes Moore and Maryland Department of the Environment Secretary Serena McIlwain to declare an air pollution emergency in the area.  Breaking News Alerts As it happens Be informed of breaking news as it happens and notified about other don't-miss content with our free news alerts. By submitting your email to receive this newsletter, you agree to our Subscriber Terms & Conditions and Privacy Policy >  â€œIn light of the commitment expressed by local, state, and federal officials to environmental justice, we implore Governor Wes Moore and Secretary Serena Mcllwain to take immediate action. Todayâ€™s nitric acid spill is not an isolated incident; it adds to a cumulative burden of environmental injustice that our community faces on a daily basis,â€ Greg Sawtell, co-president of the Community of Curtis Bay Association said.  â€œWe urge Governor Wes Moore and Secretary Serena Mcllwain to demonstrate their commitment to environmental justice by declaring an â€œAir Pollution Emergencyâ€ in Curtis Bay and allocating the necessary resources to address the chronic air pollution crisis faced by our residents,â€ he said.  Meleny Thomas, executive director of the nonprofit South Baltimore Community Land Trust, said she heard about the Friday incident from a group chat full of area residents, who were still searching for answers Friday afternoon about what substances were spilled and what precautions they should be taking.  â€They said that itâ€™s contained, but again, everything has been so vague,â€ Thomas said.  Advertisement  Even when incidents do not inflict direct harm on the community, as in the instance of the coal explosion, they add stressors to a community already burdened by industrial activity, she said.  â€These incidents continue to happen, and they add up,â€ she said. â€œSo, they have cumulative impacts.â€

HOUSTON, May 19 (Reuters) â€“ A shipment of U.S. oil is headed to South Africa for the first time in two years and destined for a Glencore-owned refinery in Cape Town that has restarted operations after an explosion shuttered it in 2020, according to ship tracking data and a source.  U.S. oil exports this year hit a record 4.5 million barrels per day as competitive pricing for U.S. grades and Chinaâ€™s reopening after COVID-19 have fueled global demand for oil.  Tanker Sonangol Porto Amboim, carrying light sweet oil, left Corpus Christi, Texas, on May 16 for Saldanha Bay on the west coast of South Africa, according to ship tracking information from Refinitiv Eikon and energy data provider Kpler.  South Africa gets most of its oil from West and Central Africa as well as Saudi Arabia, according to Kpler data. But competitive pricing for U.S. crude and changes to oil flows since Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine have opened new markets. The last shipment of U.S. oil went to South Africa in May 2021, U.S. customs data showed.  The 850,000 barrel-cargo of West Texas Light was purchased by Swiss-commodities trader Glencore GLEN.L, a person familiar with the matter said.  Glencoreâ€™s majority-owned Astron Energy restarted production at its 100,000 barrel per day Cape Town refinery nearly three years after a deadly explosion shuttered operations and killed two workers.  Glencore declined to comment on the shipment. Astron confirmed that the refinery restarted as part of a phased process and was producing at its planned capacity.  Astron, which has the second-largest retail fuel network in southern Africa, receives its oil from tankers discharging in Saldanha Bay and transports the oil to the Cape Town refinery via pipeline, according to the refinerâ€™s website.  (Reporting by Arathy Somasekhar in Houston, additional reporting by Wendell Roelf in Cape Town; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)  (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2023.

The relevant statement was made by Advisor to Mariupol Mayor Petro Andriushchenko on Telegram, an Ukrinform correspondent reports.  According to Andriushchenko, between 06:00 a.m. and 07:00 a.m., May 20, 2023, anti-aircraft defense systems again activated in Mariupolâ€™s Livoberezhnyi district. NEW DELHI: The massive blast that took place last week, in an alleged firecracker factory in West Bengalâ€™s East Medinipur district, killing at least nine people, has once again brought out how illegal firearms and bomb-making factories flourish in the hinterlands of Bengal, often with the patronage of local politicians and police.  This particular â€œfirecracker factoryâ€ in East Medinipurâ€™s Egra, that exploded on 16 May at around 12:30 pm had witnessed at least three blast incidents in the past, say sources in the local police.  The owner, a muscleman from the area, Bhanu Bagh, who lost his life that morning in the blast, was in this business for almost two decades. Locals say that with the blessings of the local politicians and the police, he grew his business, which flourished despite he having at least six cases under the Explosive Substances Act pending in various courts in the state.  A resident who spoke to The Sunday Guardian on telephone from Egra, said that it was not unknown as to what was going on in the factory. â€œEveryone knew it to be a firecracker factory, but under the garb of making firecrackers, bombs and firearms were also being manufactured. Everyone knew about it, even the police knew. Everyone got their share, so they will stay silent. During the last elections (municipal elections), a lot of bombs and ammunitions went from here. I donâ€™t know where these went, but people would come at night and collect their parcels,â€ the resident who did not wish to be identified, told this newspaper.  Another resident, who is a leader in Egra, said that Bagh was a well-connected man, and that in October 2022, his factory was raided and sealed, but within a month, he secured a bail from the courts and came back and restarted his operations. â€œWe donâ€™t understand, every time he was caught, he secured a bail within a month and restarted his operations. He was a strongman. His son and wife, all are involved in this business. They make huge money from this and therefore everyone is kept happy and nothing happens to them in the long run. But look at destiny; this same factory has killed him now,â€ he told this correspondent.  The Mamata Banerjee led government, after three days of the incident, transferred the Station House Officer in charge of Egra police station, Mausam Chakraborty, and handed over the investigation to the CID.  Experts and political analysts say that bomb making factories and â€œillegal firecracker factoriesâ€ in every rural district Bengal, have become like a â€œcottage industryâ€ that operates with much impunity. This is also evident from the large number of bomb explosion cases that have been registered in West Bengal.  Officials say that districts like Malda, Murshidabad, Birbhum, North 24 Parganas, South 24 Parganas, Burdwan have many illegal factories that make crude bombs and firearms. Apparently, this trade is often practised and passed on by families from generation to generation in the rural areas.  â€œRural Bengal does not have much employment opportunities, most of the youths are either into farming, or small-time work and many get themselves involved in such illegal businesses as this helps them earns a quick a buck and patronage from local politicians. The making of illegal crude bombs and country pistols and bullets is undertaken by generational makers who often operate these small factories within their premises or in small hutments in open fields. The demand for their products increases during elections, political rallies and to settle scores between politicians and musclemen. It has now become a question of survival for many in rural Bengal,â€ a former police officer, told this correspondent.  The large seizures of explosives from houses and fields, and incidents of high and low intensity bomb explosions are rampant in Bengal. In the last three months alone, at least five incidents of bomb explosions have been reported from West Bengal.  In February, bombs were hurled during clashes between Trinamool Congress workers in Birbhum. The incident killed two people. In March, during the Ram Navami processions in Howrah and Raiganj, bombs were hurled, gun shots fired; in March again, a crude bomb went off at the house of a TMCâ€™s district level leader in Birbhum.  The National Investigation Agency (NIA) in the last three years has registered at least 10 cases of bomb blast and explosion under the Explosive Substances Act in Bengal in various districts of the. All of these are currently under investigation.

Brandon Valenzuelaâ€™s return trip to the Midwest League is going much, much better this time around.  The 22-year-old catcher has homered twice in May and is hitting .302/.413/.547 with three homers through his first 17 games in a repeat assignment at high Single-A Fort Wayne.  A $100,000 signee out of Mexico in July 2017, Valenzuela hit himself onto the prospect radar in 2021, pairing six homers with a .307/.389/.444 batting line in 82 games at low Single-A Lake Elsinore.  Advertisement  He held his own in a 15-game call-up to the Midwest League that year (.742 OPS) but saw his numbers dip to .209/.334/.348 despite hitting a career-high 10 homers in 99 games with the TinCaps.  A heady catcher who works well with pitching staffs, Valenzuela rededicated himself to his conditioning this offseason, shedding 12 pounds and cutting his body fat by 4 to 5 percent entering spring training.  The improvements have allowed him to expand his range while blocking balls behind the plate and improve his bat speed. A year of maturity has also allowed the left-handed-hitting Valenzuela to improve his approach at the plate as heâ€™s cut his strikeout rate from 31 percent in that 15-game call-up with Fort Wayne to 23 percent last year to 20 percent this year.  Hence the jump in slugging from .348 a year ago to .547 so far this year.  â€œI think heâ€™s taking his shots a little bit more knowing he can control the strike zone,â€ Padres assistant farm director Mike Daly said. â€œHeâ€™s not afraid to hit with two strikes and thatâ€™s allowed him to be more aggressive.â€  Valenzuela is ranked No. 30 among Padres prospects as ranked by MLB.com.  Storm games postponed  Low Single-A Lake Elsinoreâ€™s games on Friday and Saturday were canceled after a gas explosion injured two contracted workers at The Diamond on Friday.  The Padres issued a statement in which they said no organizational players or personnel were involved in the incident.  Follow The Press-Enterpriseâ€™s coverage here. Thousands of residents living more than 1500km apart have all witnessed the same incredible sight â€“ a huge meteor crashing in Queensland in a spectacular light display.  Sightings came from Mackay, up to Weipa and as far inland as Mt Isa as the sky flashed green, then orange on Saturday night at around 9.20pm.  One resident in the rural town of Normanton captured the moment the display interrupted an event at the local oval.  The meteor was spotted over the airport in Cairns. Source: Facebook/Cairns Airport  Sharelle Bee captured the moment the sky turned from green to orange with the huge flash. Source: Facebook/Sharelle Bee  Sharelle Bee posted a video to Facebook, where it quickly gained 1500 shares.  â€œIt was so bright and it ended in an explosion,â€ she wrote. â€œMy heart skipped a beat and started racing.â€  Cairns Airport shared vision of the moment the flash of light arcs over the nearby mountain ranges. Others thought they had seen lightning or â€œaliensâ€ â€“ describing the scenes as â€œcrazyâ€ and â€œso scaryâ€.  â€œWe felt the explosion here in Croydon and big loud bang,â€ resident Kia Peterson wrote on Facebook.  Another Croydon local said they heard the â€œbiggest bangâ€ and said it was â€œscaryâ€.  The bang could be attributed to the meteor â€˜explodingâ€™ nearby, astronomer Ian Maclean told The Cairns Post.  â€œClearly itâ€™s exploded in the upper atmosphere somewhere in the Gulf region, west of Cairns and was felt and heard in Croydon,â€ Mr Maclean said.  He added the meteorâ€™s light, at its peak, was as bright as the sun.  Australian National Universityâ€™s Dr Brad Tucker told the ABC the meteor was likely 50cm to 100cm long, and would have been travelling at speeds of up to 150,000 km/h.  Yahoo News has contacted CSIRO for more information.  Do you have a story tip? Email: newsroomau@yahoonews.com.  You can also follow us on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Twitter and download the Yahoo News app from the App Store or Google Play.

High costs cast shadow over ChatGPT revolution  WASHINGTON  The explosion of generative AI has taken the world by storm, but one question all too rarely comes up: Who can afford it?  OpenAI bled around $540 million last year as it developed ChatGPT and says it needs $100 billion to meet its ambitions.  â€œWeâ€™re going to be the most capital-intensive startup in Silicon Valley history,â€ OpenAIâ€™s founder Sam Altman told a U.S Senate panel recently.  And when Microsoft, which poured billions of dollars in investment into OpenAI, is asked about how much its AI adventure will cost, the company answers with assurances that it is keeping an eye on its bottom line.  Building something even near the scale of what OpenAI, Microsoft or Google have on offer would require an eye-watering investment on state-of-the-art chips and recruiting prize-winning researchers.  â€œPeople donâ€™t realize that to do a significant amount of AI things like ChatGPT takes huge amounts of processing power. And training those models can cost tens of millions of dollars,â€ said Jack Gold, an independent analyst.  â€œHow many companies can actually afford to go out and buy 10,000 Nvidia H100 systems that go for tens of thousands of dollars a piece?â€ asked Gold.  The answer is pretty much no one and in tech, if you canâ€™t build the infrastructure, you rent it and that is what companies already do massively by outsourcing their computing needs to Microsoft, Google and Amazonâ€™s AWS.  And with the advent of generative AI, this dependency on cloud computing and tech giants deepens, leaving the same players in the driverâ€™s seat, experts warned.  From Main Street to Fortune 500, the dependency on the AI-amped will be an expensive one and companies and investors are drumming up alternatives to at least reduce the bill.  â€œAI training, GPT training will become a very important cloud service going forward,â€ said Spectro Cloud CEO Tenry Fu.â€œBut after training, a company will be able to get their model back for real AI applicationâ€ and the dependence on the cloud giants will hopefully be reduced, he added.  Regulators are hoping that they can keep up, and not leave the giants in charge, imposing their terms on smaller companies.  But it might be too late, at least when it comes to which companies have the means to provide the groundwork of generative AI.  â€œIt is absolutely true that the number of companies that can train the true frontier models is going to be small just because of the resources required,â€ Altman told the panel last week.  â€œAnd so I think there needs to be incredible scrutiny on us and our competitors,â€ he added.

Gas Pipe Explosion Causes Fire  Duration: 06:46  Occurred on April 20, 2023 / Bourg-de-Peage, France: "A gas pipe exploded all the inhabitants were able to evacuate no serious injuries just a few people inconvenienced by the smoke the power was cut for a few hours and was restored in the evening."

We all know fit is vital for players once they enter the NFL. Not just quarterbacks. From scheme to type of teammates, environment is often the imperceptible element that makes or breaks a young player as he's acclimating to the league.  Let's pinpoint the absolute best fits from the 2023 NFL Draft.  If you're going to play corner in Wink Martindale's system, you're going to need to be comfortable covering on an island in press man. Over the past few seasons, as the Ravens and Giants defensive coordinator, Martindale has been the league's most blitz-happy play-caller, and with that comes a need for suffocating man-to-man ability in the secondary.  That's precisely where Banks thrives. At 6-foot and right around 200 pounds with quality albeit unspectacular length, ridiculous explosion and clear-to-see natural mirroring skills, Banks was born to play on the perimeter in Martindale's system.  Benton is an ultra-physical, stunningly explosive nose tackle with an assertive play style and powerful hands. A three-down defender who's just as apt to crumble the pocket on third down as he is to blow up a run play behind the line, Benton feels like a classic Steelers interior defensive lineman who's going to bring it every snap he's on the field.  From size and athleticism angles, Benton's almost identical to former Dolphins first-round pick Christian Wilkins, and that's the type of hyper-active, pesky defensive tackle who will thrive next to Cam Heyward and across from T.J. Watt and Alex Highsmith in Pittsburgh.  The Bills -- and head coach Sean McDermott -- adore themselves some fast, explosive linebackers. Size be damned. Sure, in 2018, GM Brandon Beane ascended the board to pick the gargantuan Tremaine Edmunds after Josh Allen was selected. Since then, the team has had no issue picking smaller second-level defenders if they explode to the football and are plus coverage players.  That precisely describes Williams, the former Tulane star. A hair under 6-1 and 228 pounds, he's almost exactly the same size as Buffalo's All-Pro linebacker Matt Milano, and he clocked a 4.49 in his 40-yard dash at the combine, which placed in the 94th percentile among linebackers since 1999. He also had 13 pass breakups and two interceptions in his final three seasons for the Green Wave. He's very adept at understanding where he needs to be to follow route combinations and demonstrated awesome awareness when the football was arriving, an advanced skill many linebacker prospects simply do not possess when they enter the NFL.  There's so much DeMarcus Lawrence to Fehoko's on-field profile. Fehoko is actually a bit bigger and plays with better hand work than Lawrence did when he entered the league. In terms of non-stop hustle and outstanding conditioning, the two edge rushers are extremely comparable.  Micah Parsons has become the alpha rusher in Dallas, obviously. Lawrence still lingers as a wily veteran. And the club picked the uber-talented Sam Williams in the second round last year. Fehoko, just like Lawrence did, has the advanced pass-rushing repertoire to outplay his draft position. He registered 153 pressures across 958 pass-rushing snaps in his final three seasons at San Jose State. It's incredibly challenging to maintain such efficiency with that much volume. Fehoko did it. Glorious fit in Dan Quinn's system that prioritizes the front four getting pressure without having to blitz too often.  In the Brian Gutekunst era for the Packers, the organization has emphasized legitimate versatility with their edge rushers, from the signing of Preston Smith and Za'Darius Smith to the utilization of Dean Lowry up and down the line of scrimmage. Brooks is the next in line. I'm not even sure if he should primarily rush from the inside or get after the quarterback from a two-point stance on the edge of the opposing offensive line. He's equally good at both. That's for Green Bay to decide.  While Brooks did not test particularly well for either spot, he looked extraordinarily light-footed on film and generated the most pressures in 2022 among all players who declared for the 2023 draft. How'd he do that? With nasty swim and swipe moves, deceptive bend and high-level hustle to the quarterback.  Michael Onwenu. Joe Thuney. Ted Karras. Shaq Mason. Hjalte Froholdt. Marcus Cannon. Bill Belichick has a knack for discovering quality blockers after the second round in the draft. Sow is next.  A four-year, full-time starter at Eastern Michigan, Sow is ready for any blitz variation or any sized defensive tackle. He's seen it all. At nearly 6-foot-5 and 320-plus pounds with elite athleticism and serious power for the guard spot, he will hit the ground running in the NFL. Frankly, I have no clue why Sow was still available in the fourth round, given the deficit of reliable guard play in the league today.  In their Super Bowl-winning 2022 season, the Chiefs proved the offense was Tyreek Hill proof. Patrick Mahomes had his most efficient campaign as a passer since 2018, when he won MVP. How did Kansas City do it? Scheming and tremendous yards after the catch.  During the regular season, the Chiefs accumulated the most yards after the catch in the NFL (2,850 yards) with the third-most yards after the catch per reception (6.55). Where does Rice truly thrive? Yes, you guessed it. With the ball in his hands, after the catch. In his final two seasons at SMU, Rice forced 35 missed tackles on 160 receptions. Enormous elusiveness rate there. His size and athleticism profiles were spitting images of Brandon Aiyuk. That's who Rice can be in this Patrick Mahomes-powered offense.  3. Christian Gonzalez, CB, Patriots  Like Banks with the Giants, Gonzalez's game is tailor-made to slot into the No. 1 cornerback spot in Belichick's defense. Nearly 6-foot-2 and 200 pounds with 4.38 speed, a 41.5-inch vertical and smooth lateral mobility, there won't be many receivers who can simply "out-athletic" Gonzalez in genuine one-on-one situations.  After losing J.C. Jackson in free agency last offseason, New England has needed to reinstall that true alpha corner to the defense. Belichick got one in Gonzalez, who mirrors like a five-year NFL veteran.  2. Devon Achane, RB, Dolphins  In your mind, if you want to flip No. 1 and No. 2 here, I'm cool with it. Both are extraordinary fits from every perceivable angle. Achane is who Mike McDaniel would create in Madden for his offense. Feisty, one-cut type and, of course, most importantly, stupidly fast. Achane's 4.32 tied for the fifth-fastest 40-yard dash time for a running back in the officially recorded combine era (dating back to 1999). He isn't a super-nifty side-to-side back nor is he a bulldozer through traffic. He's experienced finding holes on inside runs before slamming on the accelerators. Despite his small size and speed reputation, Achane was the bellcow at Texas A&M over the past two seasons, with 326 carries, many of which came between the tackles.  I really wrestled with the top two picks here, but I'll go with the quarterback at the top spot simply due to positional value. Richardson's coach, Shane Steichen, was integral to Jalen Hurts' development in Philadelphia. That was well documented during the pre-draft process. Let's not forget Steichen was the Chargers' offensive coordinator during Justin Herbert's epic rookie season in 2022. And really, there's a case to be made that Richardson is a mix of Hurts and Herbert in terms of his overall capabilities at the quarterback position.  Expect plenty of designed runs and play-action deep shots from Richardson in Year 1 with the Colts. Like Steichen did with Hurts in his first full season as the Eagles starter, Richardson will be provided ample easy, high-percentage throws, too. Indianapolis swung for the fences with its first selection in the 2023 draft, and the Richardson-Steichen fit is exquisite.

Patiala: A snack shop near Railway crossing No. 22 in Patiala city was gutted on Saturday morning. Two LPG cylinders kept in the shop also exploded, leaving the residents in panic. The fire tenders rushed to the spot and doused the flames after being informed about the incident around 8:40 am.No casualties or injuries were reported in the incident. The fire is believed to have been caused by a short circuit.The cylinder blasts occurred just when the fire tenders reached the spot, said assistant divisional fire officer Surinder Kumar . â€œThere were four cylinders in the shop of which two exploded. There was leakage in the third cylinder, while the fourth cylinder was lying empty in the shop, which used to sell snacks,â€ said the officer.â€œPeople witnessed a fire in the shop and informed us. The other shops in the area were closed. None of our team members or any local were injured in the incident. The flames were doused by 10 am. Three other shops â€“ a specs shop, a photo studio and a boutique â€“ were also affected,â€ said Kumar.â€œAs the fire brigade reached the spot, two out of four cylinders in the shop exploded, but there was no casualty. The shops in the area were closed due to which the fire tenders did not face any hassle in dousing the flames. Around 12 firemen and four fire vans were employed to douse the flames,â€ he added.The fire officials pointed out the lack of fire extinguishers in all the neighboring shops and even in the affected shops. The officials said inspections would be carried out in the area besides creating awareness.
